questions.text: A 45 y/o male presents with recurrent pain, fever, and purulent discharge from a sinus tract on his tibia, 10 years after an open fracture. Radiological imaging shows a bone cavity with thickened cortices. What is the cornerstone of treatment in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Chronic Osteomyelitis

Surgical Intervention

(Option B)



 
  • Sequestrectomy: Removal of dead bone (sequestrum) to eliminate the source of infection.
  • Saucerisation: Reshaping the bone cavity to prevent pus accumulation and promote drainage.
  • Curettage: Scraping infected tissue from the bone cavity, followed by filling with antibiotic beads or muscle flaps.
  • Excision of Infected Bone: Complete removal of severely infected bone segments, if feasible.
  • Bone Transport (Ilizarov Technique): Used to regenerate bone after excision of infected segments.
  • Soft Tissue Coverage: Skin grafts or flaps to cover exposed bone, are essential for healing.
  • Vaccum-assisted covering(Negative pressure wound therapy): Promotes granulation tissue formation

Antibiotic Therapy

(Option A ruled out)
  • Antibiotics help control infection but are ineffective alone without surgery.
  • Antibiotics are chosen based on the specific bacteria identified in cultures. Eg. Fusidic acid, clindamycin and cephalosporins.
  • Typically involves 4-6 weeks of intravenous antibiotics, followed by oral therapy for 3-6 weeks.

Post-Treatment Care
  • Regular follow-up to detect any recurrence.
  • Avoid trauma to the affected area to prevent reactivation.

questions.text: A 6 y/o boy presents with a 2-day history of a painful limp. He has mild pain referred to the thigh and a low-grade fever of 37.5°C. O/E, he shows limited internal rotation of the hip and is unable to bear full weight, but remains otherwise well. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Based on the image, identify the structures indicated by the arrows

options.label: A
options.text: Yellow: Sequestrum, White: Cloaca, Red: Involucrum

options.label: B
options.text: Yellow: Involucrum, White: Sequestrum, Red: Cloaca

options.label: C
options.text: Yellow: Cloaca, White: Involucrum, Red: Sequestrum

options.label: D
options.text: Yellow: Sequestrum, White: Involucrum, Red: Cloaca

questions.correct_answer: D. Yellow: Sequestrum, White: Involucrum, Red: Cloaca
questions.explanation:
Sequestrum

Involucrum

Cloaca
  • Definition: A piece of dead bone separated from living bone due to infection.
  • Formation: Occurs in neglected cases of acute osteomyelitis, resulting from tissue destruction.
  • Characteristics: Size varies; can range from small spicules to large necrotic segments of the cortex.
  • Clinical Significance: Remains entombed within the bone, inaccessible for destruction or repair.
  • Definition: New bone formation around the infected zone.
  • Formation: Develops on viable surfaces in the bone and from the deep layers of the stripped periosteum.
  • Characteristics: Initially porotic, becomes thicker to form a casing around the sequestrum and infected tissue.
  • Clinical Significance: Can help enclose and isolate the infection, but may lead to permanent deformity if healing is inadequate.
  • Definition: Perforations in the involucrum that allow discharge of pus and bone debris.
  • Formation: Develops as the infection persists, leading to small openings through which material can escape.
  • Characteristics: Creates a path for the pus to track through sinuses to the skin surface.
  • Clinical Significance: Indicates the chronicity of osteomyelitis, leading to intermittent discharge through sinuses.

questions.text: A 23 y/o male presents with wrist pain and stiffness after months of repetitive wrist use in sports. Examination reveals tenderness over the lunate bone. MRI shows ischemic necrosis of the lunate. What is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient’s condition?

A 14 y/o male presents with pain and swelling over his tibial tuberosity following physical activity. O/E, there is a tender lump over the tibial tubercle. An X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 12-year-old boy presents with anterior knee pain that worsens with activity, particularly while running and jumping. Physical examination reveals tenderness at the inferior pole of the patella, and X-rays show no significant abnormalities. Which of the following conditions is most likely diagnosed in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Various osteochondritis

Location of osteochondritis

Sinding-Larsen-Johansson

Patella

Osgood-Schlatter (Option A ruled out)

Tibial tuberosity

Sever (Option C ruled out)

Calcaneum

Hawkins

Talus

Freiberg

2nd Metatarsal

Islene

5th Metatarsal

Haas

Head of Humerus

Panner

Capitulum

Preiser

The proximal pole of the scaphoid

Keinbock

Lunate

Friedrich’s

Clavicle

Scheuermann

Rim of the vertebral body

Calve’s

Centre of the vertebral body

Perthes disease (Legg-calve’s-Perthes disease)(Option D ruled out)

Head of Femur

questions.text: A 10 y/o girl with Gaucher's disease presents with worsening hip pain and limited range of motion. Imaging shows avascular necrosis of the femoral head. Which of the following clinical features is most likely to accompany her diagnosis?

A 45-year-old male patient presents with hip pain and limited mobility. MRI findings suggest early resorptive changes, but X-rays appear normal. According to Ficat and Arlet staging, what is the most likely stage of avascular necrosis (AVN) for this patient?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:

Stage 0

(Option A ruled out)
  • Preclinical and preradiological, AVN is suggested only if diagnosed in another area (e.g., opposite hip).

Stage 1
  • Early resorptive phase; X-rays normal, but changes seen on MRI or bone scintigraphy.

Stage 2

(Option C ruled out)
  • Reparative stage with normal femoral head contour; early signs of reactive subchondral changes.

Stage 3

(Option D ruled out)
  • The early collapse of the femoral head with clear X-ray signs of osteonecrosis, structural damage, and bone outline distortion.

Stage 4
  • Collapse of the articular surface with secondary osteoarthritis (OA).

Early Stages (0-2)
  • Watchful waiting for lesions in non-weight-bearing joints.
  • Drug therapy (e.g., bisphosphonates, statins) may help.
  • Medullary decompression and bone grafting for femoral head necrosis.
  • Unloading osteotomy to preserve anatomy in weight-bearing joints.

Intermediate Stage (3)
  • Realignment osteotomy with/without curettage and bone grafting of the necrotic segment.

Late Stage (4)
  • Non-operative management: pain control, activity modification.
  • Arthrodesis for stability (e.g., ankle, wrist).
  • Joint replacement (hip, knee, shoulder).

questions.text: A 28 y/o woman presents with persistent knee pain after recently undergoing bariatric surgery. She reports a history of significant weight loss and intermittent joint swelling. MRI was taken which revealed the following. What is the most likely reason behind this patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Postoperative autoimmune response leading to synovitis

options.label: B
options.text: Fat embolism from rapid adipose tissue breakdown

questions.correct_answer: B. Fat embolism from rapid adipose tissue breakdown
questions.explanation:
Causes of Osteonecrosis

Trauma:

Fractures or dislocations disrupt blood supply, especially in the femoral neck, scaphoid, and talus.

Corticosteroid Use:

High-dose steroids cause fat cell swelling and intravascular stasis, leading to bone ischemia

Alcohol Abuse:

Chronic alcohol use leads to fat embolism and marrow swelling, causing venous stasis.

Sickle Cell Disease:

Sickled red cells obstruct blood vessels, leading to ischemia and bone death.

Gaucher’s Disease:

Lipid accumulation in bone marrow causes vascular compression and ischemia

Thrombophilia:

Increased blood clotting tendency leads to capillary thrombosis, causing bone necrosis.

Antiphospholipid Antibodies:

As seen in SLE, these antibodies promote clot formation, leading to ischemia.

Fat Embolism:

Fat emboli block capillaries, causing endothelial damage and thrombosis.

Venous Stasis:

Marrow swelling increases intraosseous pressure, leading to venous blockage and ischemia.

Dysbaric Osteonecrosis:.

Rapid decompression (e.g., in divers) causes gas bubbles in vessels, leading to bone necrosis.

Pregnancy:

Hormonal changes and fatty liver can decrease fibrinolysis, increasing clot formation.

Radiation Exposure:

Radiation damages blood vessels, leading to poor blood flow and bone necrosis

questions.text: A 40 y/o man presents with severe knee pain and swelling after drinking contaminated water from a stepwell in Rajasthan. Upon examination, a painful inflamed lesion with a visible adult worm is noted on his leg. Which of the following is the primary method for diagnosing the patient's condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Joint aspiration for synovial fluid analysis

questions.correct_answer: B. Visual inspection of the lesion
questions.explanation:
Smallpox Osteomyelitis (Osteomyelitis Variolosa)

Guinea Worm Arthritis
  • Cause: Osteoarticular involvement from Variola major virus during childhood smallpox infection.
  • Affected Areas: Symmetrical involvement, primarily in elbows (80%), wrists, ankles, hands, and feet; spine and pelvis are rarely involved.
  • Symptoms: Gradual swelling of joints, leading to bone deformities and joint instability.
  • Diagnosis-
    • Clinical Examination: Detection of bilateral, symmetrical joint deformities
  • Treatment: Self-limiting- The condition cannot be prevented or repaired.
  • Seen endemic in Rajasthan, due to the use of stepwells.
  • Cause: Infection with Dracunculus medinensis from drinking water containing infected copepods.
  • Symptoms: Painful, inflamed skin lesion containing an adult worm.
  • Diagnosis: Visual inspection of the lesion; calcified worms can be detected via X-ray.
  • Treatment: Slow, careful removal of the adult worm.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant presents with a fever of 102°F, irritability, and refusal to bear weight on the right leg. Physical examination reveals tenderness and swelling around the right hip joint. An ultrasound shows significant joint effusion. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic due to poor feeding and lethargy. On examination, the physician notes a diffuse rash, hepatosplenomegaly, and a swollen left knee joint, indicating early congenital syphilis. Which of the following findings can be seen in early congenital syphilis?
questions.explanation:
Congenital syphilis

Acquired syphilis
  • Cause: Transplacental transmission during pregnancy.
  • Early congenital syphilis:
    • Diagnosed from birth through 2 years of age
    • Parrot’s Syphilitic Joint: congenital syphilis complication with periostitis and pain.Leads to joint effusion, epiphysitis, and limited movement.
    • X-rays: Osteochondritis (lucent bands near physis), periostitis (mild or ‘onion-peel’ effect).
  • Late congenital syphilis:
    • Diagnosed after 2 years of birth
    • Features: Gummata and other bone lesions
    • Sabre tibia-the tibial bone has a pronounced anterior bowing (i.e., bends forward)(Option B ruled out)
    • Hutchinson’s teeth (Option A ruled out)- abnormal. Notched teeth
    • Clutton’s joints - Painless swelling in elbows and knees.
    • Parrot's sign, or 'Parrot's nodes'/'Parrot's bosses,' refers to bony growths observed on the skulls of children with congenital syphilis.
    • Higoumenakis' sign refers to the enlargement of the sternal end of the right clavicle
  • Early acquired syphilis:
    • Painful/tender bones: Frontal skull bones, tibia, sternum, ribs.
    • X-rays: Periostitis, thickened cortex
    • Hydrarthrosis:
  • Late acquired syphilis:
    • Syphilitic gumma: Granulomatous lesions with bone resorption, sclerosis.
    • Charcot’s Joint: Nerve damage leads to loss of sensation in the joint, most commonly affecting the foot and ankle. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 35-year-old milkman presents with a three-week history of fluctuating low-grade fevers, drenching night sweats, and severe lower back pain. He reports increasing discomfort in his hips and knees, particularly after long days of work. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Aetiology
  • Caused by Brucella melitensis, Brucella abortus (cattle), and Brucella suis (pigs).
  • Transmission via unpasteurized milk or contact with infected meat (farmers, meat handlers).

Pathology
  • Entry through infected milk, skin, or mucosal surfaces.
  • Spreads via lymphatics and bloodstream to bones (often vertebral bodies) or synovium.
  • Granulomatous inflammation

Common Sites
  • Sacroiliac and spinal joints are most frequently involved

Clinical Features
  • Initial symptoms: Alternating fever and improvement phases (undulant fever), headache, generalized weakness, joint pains, and backache.
  • Joint involvement: Pain, swelling, tenderness, restricted movement (commonly in hip, knee, spine).

X-ray Findings
  • Subacute arthritis with articular space loss, bone erosion, and periarticular osteoporosis.
  • Spine: Destruction and collapse of vertebral bodies, disc obliteration

Treatment
  • Antibiotics: Tetracycline + streptomycin (3–4 weeks)
  • Surgery: Drainage of abscess, excision of necrotic tissue, arthrodesis/arthroplasty if joint destruction occurs.

questions.text: A 50 y/o woman with chronic osteomyelitis presents with a draining sinus and increasing pain in her leg. Which of the following is not a potential complication of her condition?

Which of the following statements about osteomyelitis is true? The most common site for hematogenous spread of infection in adults is the thoracolumbar spine. The most common organism found in patients using intravenous drugs is Salmonella typhi. The most common organism in children aged 1 to 4 years is Haemophilus influenza. The metaphysis of the distal femur and proximal tibia is the most common site of infection in children aged 2 to 6 years. The most common organism in sickle-cell disease is Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

A 50 y/o male presents with a history of recurring pain, fever, and a discharging sinus on his right leg for several months. He reports being treated for osteomyelitis during childhood. Which of the following investigations would be most useful to visualise the extent of soft tissue involvement in this patient?
What radiological feature distinguishes a sequestrum from living bone in a case of osteomyelitis?

A 45 y/o man with a history of tuberculosis presents with a chronic draining sinus on his left tibia. Radiographic imaging shows multiple bone lesions with areas of necrosis. Given his medical history and the radiological findings, what type of sequestrum is most likely present?
questions.explanation:
Types of Sequestrum

Type

Disease

Tubular (Option A ruled out)

Pyogenic

Ring (Option B ruled out)

External Fixator

Black

Actinomycosis

Coralliform

Perthe’s Disease

Coke (Option C)

Tuberculosis

Sandy

Tuberculosis

Feathery/ Ivory (Option D ruled out)

Syphilis

questions.text: A 38 y/o male presents with chronic pain and intermittent purulent discharge from a sinus over his right tibia, which developed after a fracture sustained 8 months ago. An X-ray shows the following finding. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the persistence of his infection?
questions.correct_answer: A. Lack of initial antibiotic therapy

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of an open tibial fracture 2 years ago presents with intermittent pain, redness, and a discharging sinus at the injury site for the past 2 months. He has occasional low-grade fever and tenderness with scarring on examination. X-ray shows cortical thickening and bone deformity. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old male has had dull, aching pain in his right tibia for 6 months, with intermittent swelling and mild fever. X-ray shows cortical thickening and increased bone density. Biopsy reveals no abscess, and cultures are negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10 y/o child presents with localised pain and swelling in the lower leg. Radiographic examination reveals a circumscribed, round area of lucency in the metaphysis of the tibia, surrounded by a halo of sclerosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 10-year-old boy presents with acute fever pain and tenderness in his right leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Wait for culture and sensitivity results before starting antibiotics

questions.correct_answer: C. Start empirical IV antibiotics immediately
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:

Treatment

Details

Antimicrobial Therapy

  • Immediate empirical IV antibiotics. (Option C)
  • Antibiotics are switched to targeted drugs after culture results. (Option A ruled out)
  • Antibiotic course involves IV for 2–4 weeks, followed by oral for 3–6 weeks. (Option B ruled out).

Surgical Drainage

  • Indicated if no improvement is observed within 36 hours, signs of deep pus, or aspirated pus. (Option D ruled out)
  • Abscess is drained via open surgery, drilling, or creating a cortical window.

Splintage & Rest
  • Recommended for comfort and to prevent joint contractures.
  • Methods include skin traction, plaster slab, or half-cylinder depending on the site.

Supportive Treatment
  • Regular administration of analgesics for pain. IV fluids are used to address dehydration.

questions.text: A 7 y/o child presents with fever, acute tenderness, and swelling in the left leg. The child is experiencing severe pain even with a gentle touch and shows reluctance to move the limb. What is the confirmatory investigation to diagnose the child’s condition?

A 5 y/o child presents with acute tenderness in the groin, refusing to move the affected leg, and appears to have a "paralyzed" limb. Upon examination, even gentle manipulation causes significant pain. Which of the following conditions could be a potential cause of this condition?
Which of the following statements about Hobo's and Trueta's theories of acute osteomyelitis is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Hobo suggested that acute osteomyelitis develops due to sluggish blood flow in capillary loops.

options.label: B
options.text: Hobo indicated that infection in the metaphysis occurs primarily due to direct invasion of the periosteum.

options.label: C
options.text: Trueta's theory states that infection begins in “blood lakes” at the intrametaphyseal capillary loop where blood flow is faster.

options.label: D
options.text: Growth cartilage completely protects the epiphysis from infection spread in infants.

questions.correct_answer: A. Hobo suggested that acute osteomyelitis develops due to sluggish blood flow in capillary loops.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the hospital with a 7-day history of severe pain in her proximal tibia, accompanied by fever and swelling. Imaging studies show signs of bone infection. Which of the following findings would most likely be observed by the end of Week 1 of infection? Formation of granulation tissue around the infection. Development of a subperiosteal abscess. Presence of sequestra. Involucrum formation.
